-1 to this.

currently the perodic task does retrive the pci info in update_avaiable_resouces but it never updates
it in the db or in memory.

the db should only be updated when the compute agent starts as it is done today.
its debatabel if we we even want to keep the current behavior in the perodic task that we have today.

nova doe s not currently support adding or removing pci device to the hypervior without a compute agent and somethimes
libvirt restart.

With my downstream hat on we dont support hardware updated inplace as we do not support chaning the number of VF or updating
pci whitelist whiel vms are on the hosts. its too easy to break exisitng vms if we allowed that. you have to drain
the host of vms then perform the hardware updates and then you can use it for new vms.

i am not sure that it makes sense to extend upstream to track device change at runtime in a periodic upstream either
as nova has no support for moving allocation betwween equivalent devices if a device that was in use was removed.


if other agree we could adress this in a followup as this is more of an implemeation nit.

Fair enough, I was trying to be as generic as possible since saw this in the Nova code base:

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/tag/23.0.1/nova/pci/manager.py#L106-L108
"        To support pci device hot plug, we sync with the hypervisor
        periodically, fetching all devices information from hypervisor,
        update the tracker and sync the DB information."

I have not seen a lot (if any) requests for PCIe hot-plug in my practice so this is definitely not something I am looking for in the initial implementation.

Will adjust the text accordingly.

here you are refering to a warm reboot vs a cold reboot.

warm reboots  are initacited by the host os and typically do not result in the disruption of power to the pci slot although that
depened on the uefi/kernel behavior. could reboot such as whne you do a reset via ipmi disconnect the power and reconencts it

cold reboot involve fully powering fo the server and renergising it which would reload firmware exctra form flash on all cards.

so in a warm reboot the DPUs proably will continue to be online during the host os reboot process but for a cold reboot
then they would be powered off with the server and the other pci devices.

Yes, there may be platform-dependent behaviors for sure.

I can change this to: "in contrast, a warm reboot is likely to keep a SmartNIC DPU powered on".

so i think this is proably the part of the spec that we might need to consider more closely.
i agree that in general i dont think this should have a large upgrade impact.

any host that does not use this feature should have 0 impact and i think that will more or less be the case with this proposal.

the only aspect might be an issue is the initall agent start after upgrade may need to upgrade teh pci_device tables entries to sotre the extra info for the serial number ectra

i think we should call this out here so that larger clouds are aware of this as that coudl cause issues if you rebooted them all at once.
other then that however i the current form of the spec avoid all the upgrade issues that the original one had as there are no db or nova api changes involved.
there is also a dependency on neutron being upgraded too to use the feature but

Agreed.

As for Neutron, this is more of an operational concern in terms of service upgrade ordering. However, it would be good to think through the situation with usage of Neutron API (and this feature) happening before a Neutron upgrade. Since Neutron is assumed to have an older version, it cannot react to the newly added data in the request. It also does not have microversions that could have been used in the case of Nova. So we need something else.
has this been implemented yet in ovn?

We are trying to get it fully agreed on upstream: there is a certain challenge in orchestrating the inclusion of various bits across 3 projects (one of them being outside OpenStack).

https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/project/ovn/patch/20210509140305.1910796-1-frode.nordahl@canonical.com/#2699171

oh oke this is the code for the ovn plugging.

i think we would need this to be merged upstream in ovn and in a release before we can merge the nova code.

and the same woudl be ture of the ovs netlink-devlnk support.

is this likely to be inculded in an upstream ovs/ovn release before we reach milestone 3?

we do not speculativly merge code in nova to support a feature in an external project like ovs or
ovn before its released or at least merged in tehre master branch so this is a hard depency for the nova code to
merge but not nessisarly for the spec to be approved.

> i think we would need this to be merged upstream in ovn and in a release before we can merge the nova code.
> and the same woudl be ture of the ovs netlink-devlnk support.

Yes, I agree - hopefully we can do it as a lot of spec work in Nova and Neutron depends on it.

There is an alternative approach similar to having it directly in OVN and having a separate daemon running on a DPU to be responsible for representor plugging. It makes things more difficult in several ways:

1) Separate component to maintain outside OVN;
2) Communication patterns become more complex;
3) Changes at the Neutron side to talk to a separate daemon (whether to do it in the OVN mech driver or having 2 mech drivers is another question);
4) Neutron has been moving away from having separate agents to just using OVN NB API and it feels like a step in the opposite direction.

> is this likely to be inculded in an upstream ovs/ovn release before we reach milestone 3?

At the moment I don't have a good answer - Frode and I need some more time to get a concrete +2/-2 upstream for including this in OVN directly. Otherwise we will aim for having a separate daemon and adjust the Neutron spec accordingly.

I think regardless of which direction wins the Nova spec will stay the same.

The next step for us is to have a discussion during the Neutron Drivers Meeting and to try and get more OVN core developer opinions on Frode's patchset.

ack. i think we would also want the neutron spec to be approved or close to approval before we approve the nova spec.

effectively we should aim to merge both at the same time once both communities are happy with the design.
Ack

yep. i dont think this need to be a hard depency like the ovn support but in the long run it would be better to get this form libvirt
+1
Ack

+1 this is a good highlevel overview of the packet flow without adding too much lowlevel detail.

ack, this is a detail for the neutron implmenation by the way but we should also not
that in this congifuation, assuming no other agent is running on the hypervior host os direclty
that we will not be supporting vnic_type normal on this host.

neutron can correctly candel that at the port binding stage by rejecting to bind the port but we likely want to consider schduling based on this as well.

efectivly what im thinking is that we woudl modify neutron so that it alwasy create a port resouce request. that request would by default not request an placemnet resouce classes adn only contain traits request for the vnic_type, network type (vxlan, geneve...) and optionaly the physnet if applicable.

we could emulate this on the nova side with a placement prefilter in the sort term but ultimately i would like to see nova expressing these types of requireemtns.

if this was in place vms with  ports of vnic_type normal could never by schduled to host that only had off path acclerators and you would not have to do anything special form a sculding point of view.

it would also be genericaly useful as we would know that a host could potentially bind the port to the correct network type and physnet before we actually select teh host in scudling and try to do bind the port on the compute node.

this is likely a sperate enhanment form this feature but i think we shoudl keep this in mind as somethign to aim for.

> ack, this is a detail for the neutron implmenation by the way but we should also not
that in this congifuation, assuming no other agent is running on the hypervior host os direclty that we will not be supporting vnic_type normal on this host.

Agreed, I will put references to specific agents in parentheses just for information. In fact, it may be something totally different from OVS and OVN at the SmartNIC DPU side - Nova doesn't even need to know what it is. I am just trying to avoid being too abstract here as somebody might be reading this out of context but it's certainly related to Neutron more than to Nova.

Will also make a note that no networking agents are expected to run on the hypervisor host in this configuration as you say - this is a pretty important distinction to note.

> if this was in place vms with  ports of vnic_type normal could never by schduled to host that only had off path acclerators and you would not have to do anything special form a sculding point of view.
> it would also be genericaly useful as we would know that a host could potentially bind the port to the correct network type and physnet before we actually select teh host in scudling and try to do bind the port on the compute node.

Right, part of the reason why I was trying to account for resources in the initial spec was that suddenly ports are no longer an "infinite" resource that can just be created - there are limits to the amount of VFs that can be allocated and "normal" ports aren't available at all.

I think what you suggest covers it well.

Do I understand correctly that the existing PCI tracking in nova-compute and the existing PCIFilter in the nova-scheduler are assumed to be not impacted by the proposed change? 

@Sean: Do this spec has any impact on your pci device tracking in placment spec https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/791047 ?

> Do I understand correctly that the existing PCI tracking in nova-compute and the existing PCIFilter in the nova-scheduler are assumed to be not impacted by the proposed change? 

Nothing except for storing some more information associated with PciDevices (the serial number from VPD, PF MAC, VF logical number).

I wish we had PCIe hierarchy IDs available for PFs and VFs in the contemporary hardware to avoid having to rely on PF MAC and VF logical numbers for VF representor lookup but I guess we have to work with what we have today and later use better means if they become available.

> so i will adapt the geneirc pci spec to supprot this spec assuming this gets approved.

Thank you for looking into this and all the work so far - this is much appreciated.

they are complementary but i think this can proceed without that spec being completed so one does not block the other.

i am going to extend that spec to cater for some of the use cases that this spec raises. namely im going to add the ablity to add traits via the pci whitelist instead fo just resouce classes.

in the current version of my spec im suggesting addign the ablity to request traits via the pci alais and i was going to have the capablies transformed into traits and reported automatically but i think haveign the abllity to add CUSTOM_ traits via the pci whitelist will allow that tagging of the device for use with this spec in a palacment native way if we want that.

so i will adapt the geneirc pci spec to supprot this spec assuming this gets approved.
Do you expect to have all pieces ready for the Xena release in October including the upstream OVS changes?

Yes, that is the goal. Frode and I are trying to get all pieces in place as fast as possible while avoiding snowflakes - we do not see much point in having anything out of tree or unapproved by the relevant upstream communities. This introduces some challenges into being able to reason about exact timelines as the whole effort is cross-project and timing is not always under our control. But I can say that it is our priority to get it done fast (and right).

I guess we don't have real hardware in upstream CI for this. So we cannot expect to have tempest coverage for the feature. Similarly how we don't have SRIOV coverage for the same reason.

I suggest, top of the unit test, to look at the tests under nova.tests.functional.libvirt I hope that env can be used to cover the proposed changes.

perhaps the melonox sriov ci could be extended if that has the correct hardeware.

i do agree that that functional test shoudl be possible and we shoudl emulate this there. that will require some enhancement to the neutron fixture and i woudl guess it would be cleaner to create a spereate neutron fixture for these tests to emulate the beahvior we expect but i think that an implemation detail that we can work out later.

I wish there was some way to emulate a machine with multiple isolated CPUs talking over PCIe in QEMU and a switchdev-capable switch - this could probably be used to emulate a system with a SmartNIC DPU.

Some useful parts are there but not enough to build a complete system.

https://github.com/qemu/qemu/blob/master/docs/specs/rocker.txt
https://people.netfilter.org/pablo/netdev0.1/papers/Rocker-switchdev-prototyping-vehicle.pdf

So:

1) unit tests - no question about it;
2) Neutron fixture - will explore what needs to be done but it seems like a decent approach while we do not have a CI with real hardware figured out;
3) Real hardware - need to explore this further as we definitely need real hw validation long-term.

Yes, the aim is to show that the design factors in a possibility of having a SmartNIC connected to multiple PCIe hierarchies (e.g. in a dual-socket system).

For the dual-socket case, I am assuming that this should result in 4 PFs exposed to a dual-socket host (2 uplink ports x 2 NUMA nodes) when bonding and PF hiding is not configured.

https://community.mellanox.com/s/article/getting-started-with-socket-direct-connectx-5-adapters-on-an-infiniband-network
"If you have two port Socket Direct Adapter, you are supposed to see PCI 4 devices, two physical and two logical, on the two PCI slots used."

https://docs.mellanox.com/display/BlueFieldSWv31011424/Multi-host
"In multi-host mode, each host interface can be divided into up to 4 independent PCIe interfaces. All interfaces would share the same physical port, and are managed by the same multi-physical function switch (MPFS). Each host would have its own e-switch and would control its own traffic."

https://docs.mellanox.com/display/BlueFieldSWv22011000/BlueField+Link+Aggregation
"# mlxconfig -d /dev/mst/mt41682_pciconf0 s HIDE_PORT2_PF=True

If you do not perform this, the function will still be visible, but it will not receive any traffic."

This sentence is not clear to me, basicly the deploy need to provide the device IDs for the smart-nic on each node. right?

Yes, this is mainly for adding the proposed "transportnode" capability to discovered PciDevices such that scheduling can be done correctly.

We don't have a distinct capability exposed by a driver via devlink so a config seems to be the only option (besides hard-coding vendor and device IDs in the code which is undesirable in my view).

What is the transport nodes config Device ID or BDF?
Why you need the VFs? can't you infer it from the pci_whitelist?

I planned to reuse the PCI whitelist code for this config and maybe restricting it to vendor_id + device ID.

It could be BDF but I don't think this is very reliable as a device could be relocated into a different slot and BDF numbers may change if things like "bus padding" are configured some time after the initial deployment.
how you plan to extract it with lspci?

2 ways:

1) via devlink (if the kernel and userspace versions allow for it and the driver exposes the board_serial via devlink-info);
2) by reading PCI VPD via sysfs (see below).

I have a python implementation for a VPD format reader (the format is described in the PCI/PCIe specs). It reads PCI VPD from a sysfs location and extracts the serial number.

https://gist.github.com/dshcherb/40e982989599a757e5b1e25999501019

The support for this sysfs file was added a long time ago so it is a good fallback:
https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-bus-pci
"What:		/sys/bus/pci/devices/.../vpd
Date:		February 2008
Contact:	Ben Hutchings <bwh@kernel.org>
Description:
		A file named vpd in a device directory will be a
		binary file containing the Vital Product Data for the
		device.  It should follow the VPD format defined in
		PCI Specification 2.1 or 2.2, but users should consider
		that some devices may have malformatted data.  If the
		underlying VPD has a writable section then the
		corresponding section of this file will be writable.
"

you want the host_id to be the DPU hostname? Maybe you should extend neutron to support
binding_host_id  - hypervisor 
binding_network_host_id - DPU

I assume that you refer to nova-compute because he will know the VF index after the claim. 
how will you pass that information? Do we have support for such communication to day?
I know in regular case after os-vif called nova-compute send notification to neutron-server. I I wonder how it will work in this case...

Yes, when nova-compute builds an instance today it will contact Neutron and provide binding_host_id and update the binding_profile field of the port. In the case of regular SR-IOV it will provide extra detail such as PCI address and such already.

So what we need to do is to extend that with the information required for looking up the correct DPU host and information about logical PF and VF that can be forwarded to OVN for representor port lookup by the ovn-controller running on the NIC.

In addition to providing information about which NIC SoC and logical VF number we need to provide information that allows identifying to which physical port on the NIC the logical VF number belongs in order to successfully look up the correct representor port.

In some scenarios the user might also want to actually plug the PF into an instance.

During prototyping of the OVN Representor Port plugging support I found that using the MAC address of the PF to be the most reliable identifier that would be visible from both the host and NIC SoC side for presently consumable kernel versions.

Using that also allows for the OVN Representor Port plugging code to plug both PF and VF representors using the same database options and code paths.

Never mind the last comment, the logical numbering does not appear to be visible to the host side through devlink-port after all. We can still determine the logical VF number from host side with other means though.

Actually, we could probably also use the logical PF number as provided by the devlink-port infrastructure. But Nova already stores the PF MAC and has existing helpers for PCI <-> MAC lookups, so I guess that is why I went with that initially.
can you elaborate on this point? why you can do code reuse with different VNIC type? Ithink it will be super important to align this work with the ironic smart-nic work that is already exist.

What I mean here is that there could be a completely different API service to track SmartNICs. I would like to avoid that and re-use the logic that already exists in Nova and Neutron with some minimal modifications.

Whether type "direct" or type "smart-nic" (introduced with the Ironic work) will be used is a secondary concern: I am trying to avoid adding yet another type besides those two and relying solely on Nova, Neutron and OVN when it comes to the services used.
so it seem that also nova-compute need to provide information to neutron on which VF port to bind. I didn't understand if it adds another communication between them
This communication already exists, either Nova will update the binding_host_id and binding_profile of the port provided at instance creation time.
how will nova know that neutron was able to plug the port?

Today nova-compute will do the following:
1) With instance paused, update Neutron binding_host_id, binding_profile
2) Plug port
2) Wait for notification from Neutron about port binding being successful
3) Resume instance

What we propose to do is to based on VNIC-type tell Nova to not attempt to do the port plugging at all. Instead it will provide neutron with the necessary information, which is then forwarded to ovn-controller running on the NIC, which then both plugs and binds the representor port.

As soon as the plugging and binding is successful Neutron will notify Nova (it already does this today) and the VM will be resumed and instance creation complete.

I see your point. I've seen the term "intelligent NIC" pushed around to refer to NICs like ConnectX ones without additional ARM cores.

I was basing those on the definitions from the referenced paper and presentation which assume that a SmartNIC has an "Application CPU" or "NIC cores". The paper also calls them collectively as "Multicore SoC SmartNICs" trying to underline the presence of additional cores (whether in the off-path or on-path architecture).

https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~arvind/papers/ipipe.pdf
"A Multicore SoC SmartNIC consists of four major parts (as shown in Figure 1-a): (1) computing units, including a general-purpose ARM/MIPS multicore processor, along with accelerators for packet processing (e.g., deep packet inspection, packet buffer management) and specialized functions (e.g., encryption/decryption, hashing, pattern matching, compression); (2) onboard memory, enclosing fast self-managed scratchpad and slower L2/DRAM; (3) traffic control module that transfers packets between TX/RX ports and the packet buffer, accompanied by an internal traffic manager or NIC switch that delivers packets to NIC cores; (4) DMA engines for communicating with the host."

"Based on ***how SmartNIC cores interact with traffic***, we further categorize SmartNICs into two types: on-path and off-path SmartNICs. The cores for on-path SmartNICs (Figure 1-b) are on the packet communication path and hold the capability to manipulate each incoming/outgoing packet"

https://netdevconf.info/0x14/pub/slides/39/Netdev%200x14%20--%20Taking%20Control%20of%20your%20SmartNIC%20v1.pdf
Slide 7 "Benefits of On-Path Architecture": "**NIC cores** have direct access to packet memory for low latency packet processing"
Slide 8 "Benefits of Off-Path Architecture": "ASIC hardware allows packets to skip **NIC cores** and go directly to host cores"

Not saying those are a single source of truth at this particular point - standardization is definitely lacking in this area and I am trying to reuse terms others have come up with as much as possible.

I propose two alternative sets of definitions to fix this:

1)
- Off-path multi-core SoC SmartNIC;
- On-path multi-core SoC SmartNIC.

2)
- Off-path SmartNIC DPU;
- On-path SmartNIC DPU.

The latter being subjectively better.

actuylly PF macs cannot be set sicne they are reset when detach form the host kernel but we should still not rely on them.

I agree, we discarded VF MACs from the beginning because of that. PF logical numbers (that we can deduce from PCI function numbers) are relative to controllers in general and we don't see them from the hypervisor host - that was a very unfortunate conclusion from looking at the actual hardware as using {PF logical number, VF logical number} combination was very compelling.

What I mean here is that storing a map of PF or VF MAC addresses to SmartNIC hostnames for lookup purposes is not feasible and that a better way is to use a serial number from VPD.

Default PF and VF MAC addresses can be programmed from the SmartNIC host side,

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/netdev/net.git/commit/?id=a1e8ae907c8d67f57432190bb742802a76516b00 (upstream API)
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/v5.12/net/core/devlink.c#L1057-L1089

https://docs.mellanox.com/display/BlueFieldSWv21010924/Controlling%20Host%20PF%20and%20VF%20Parameters (Bluefield-specific)

however, the hypervisor host can change them (at least in its own kernel) and so they will no longer be usable for lookup purposes anymore.

The scenario where only VFs are used is a bit different:

* PFs MACs are not touched;
* VF MACs are.

Therefore, default PF MACs set from the SmartNIC host can be used for consistent lookup of PFs at both sides.

This is a good point. Even if the hypervisor host can see PCIe endpoints it does not mean that the SmartNIC host will talk to PCIe endpoints at its side.

Even the switchdev docs use PCIe as an example (not as a mandatory implementation detail): https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/switchdev.txt

It could well be platform devices or some other IO bus.

My aim here was to illustrate that if PCIe is used at both sides, those topologies are isolated and that relying on PCI addresses is not an option.

This was written mostly with VFs in mind. PFs are relied on in the non-SmartNIC DPU case to retrieve the "switchdev" capability that will be associated with its VFs as well.

This is then used to specify a requirement for this capability in the binding:profile attribute:
https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-ovs-offload.html#validate-open-vswitch-hardware-offloading
# openstack port create --network private --vnic-type=direct --binding-profile '{"capabilities": ["switchdev"]}' direct_port2


Here is an example of a deployment state:
https://paste.ubuntu.com/p/yMmdjtMQQv/ (database table dumps for a deployment with OVS hardware offload. Note that the "switchdev" capability is present on both PFs and VFs)


The problem is that the NIC Switch is not exposed to the hypervisor host in the SmartNIC DPU case and for that we need to flag VFs explicitly with a certain capability to make the mechanism above work in the same way as with hardware offload (a different capability name can be used for multiplexing).

I like the generic traits direction.

so the eswitch has an id can we use that instead of the mac to identify the eswitch?

https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/d8af3568b8b92748f61029a96c46fd513b6795c2/vif_plug_ovs/linux_net.py#L411-L423

def _get_phys_switch_id(ifname):
    """Get the interface name and return its phys_switch_id
    :param ifname: The interface name
    :return: The phys_switch_id of the given ifname
    """
    phys_port_name_path = "/sys/class/net/%s/phys_switch_id" % ifname

    if not os.path.isfile(phys_port_name_path):
        return None

    with open(phys_port_name_path, 'r') as fd:
        return fd.readline().strip()

Ah, that's the core of the problem: the eSwitch is not visible at the hypervisor host.

I wish we could just use the switch ID from both sides but the hypervisor host simply sees interfaces of devlink flavors "physical" and "virtual" whereas the SmartNIC host sees "PCI PF" and "PCI VF" ones for representors. So there is no switch ID visible from the hypervisor side.

The Neutron spec references the following kernel commits that allow PF mac lookup by a PF representor (as their MACs differ):

"[11] https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=2a916ecc405686c1d86f632281bc06aa75ebae4e
[12] https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=f099fde16db3d2594a54ba8c94ce9fa3557aa3e1"

So there is a generic API to obtain this information provided the kernel driver supports it.

The problem with the switch ID is that the kernel only guarantees that it will be unique across switches within the same system. If there are multiple SmartNIC DPUs in one server, technically, it's two different systems:

https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/networking/switchdev.html#switch-id
"The switchdev driver must implement the net_device operation ndo_get_port_parent_id for each port netdev, returning the same physical ID for each port of a switch. The ID must be unique between switches on the same system. The ID does not need to be unique between switches on different systems."

So, besides this concern alone, I doubt they would want to break isolation in terms of eSwitch awareness at the host level but there is no harm in asking.


I have a potential alternative approach though with using a concept of a Hierarchy ID present in PCIe 4.0:

"7.9.18 Hierarchy ID Extended Capability
The Hierarchy ID Extended Capability provides an optional mechanism for passing a unique identifier to Functions within a Hierarchy. At most one instance of this capability is permitted in a Function. This capability is not applicable to Bridges, Root Complex Event Collectors, and RCRBs."

https://members.pcisig.com/wg/PCI-SIG/document/previewpdf/11116 (should be accessible via corp e-mail for member organizations).

If the NIC firmware exposed hierarchy IDs for PFs and VFs at the hypervisor host side and allowed querying that via PF and VF representors at the SmartNIC DPU host side, I think we would have a more reliable approach to this problem.

If this feels sane, maybe it's worth bringing up with Mellanox/NVIDIA or other vendors as a preferential feature. I can try to do that, however, I think we need to have a base case supported with what we have at this point.

Sean, it appears that we might be talking past each other on some of the details in this spec.

To demonstrate what we are proposing to do I dusted off the PoC code we did prior to writing this spec:

nova-compute PoC: https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/kbZ3zz7rPJ/
neutron-server PoC: https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/gKKvTtYTFH/
fixture ran on third host for purpose of PoC: https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/JQV6hywv7V/

As you can see we are not adding any API calls or suchlike, we are just extending the already existing conversation between Nova and Neutron.

After Nova plugs or not plugs a VIF it will already today wait for a notification from Neutron about success of port binding. Neutron does not emit this notification until it has feedback from its agents or OVN that the port is successfully bound, so even if Nova does not do any plugging it will not resume the instance until networking is fully plumbed.

no after nove pluggs the vif we wait for a network-vif-plugged event for neutron on the sucess fo the port plugging.

port bidning is what happens eariler wehn we set the binding:host-id on the neutron port.
port binding is complete when the api call returns form tha tport update.

port plugging happens after that.

def _nova_to_osvif_vif_ovs(vif):
    vif_name = _get_vif_name(vif)
    vnic_type = vif.get('vnic_type', model.VNIC_TYPE_NORMAL)
    profile = objects.vif.VIFPortProfileOpenVSwitch(
        interface_id=vif.get('ovs_interfaceid') or vif['id'],
        datapath_type=vif['details'].get(
            model.VIF_DETAILS_OVS_DATAPATH_TYPE))
    # you could also look at someing in the binidng deatails or
    # binding profile instead of using a dedicated vnic_type
    if vnic_type in (model.VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT_DPU):
       # we shoudl extend https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/master/vif_plug_noop/noop.py
       # to supprot something other then objects.vif.VIFVHostUser like 
       #  objects.vif.VIFGeneric or objects.vif.VIFHostDevice, but its not actully used in
       # this plugin.
       obj = _get_vif_instance(vif, objects.vif.VIFVHostUser,
                                plugin="noop",
                                vif_name=_get_vif_name(vif))
    elif vnic_type in (model.VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT, model.VNIC_TYPE_VDPA):
        obj = _get_vnic_direct_vif_instance(
            vif,
            port_profile=_get_ovs_representor_port_profile(vif),
            plugin="ovs")
        _set_representor_datapath_offload_settings(vif, obj)
    elif vif.is_hybrid_plug_enabled():
        obj = _get_vif_instance(
            vif,
            objects.vif.VIFBridge,
            port_profile=profile,
            plugin="ovs",
            vif_name=vif_name,
            bridge_name=_get_hybrid_bridge_name(vif))
    else:
        profile.create_port = vif.get('delegate_create', False)
        obj = _get_vif_instance(
            vif,
            objects.vif.VIFOpenVSwitch,
            port_profile=profile,
            plugin="ovs",
            vif_name=vif_name)
        if vif["network"]["bridge"] is not None:
            obj.bridge_name = vif["network"]["bridge"]
    return obj

Let me try to explain this better.

The suggestion isn't to add any new API calls to the process from the Nova side.

Nova would merely pass additional information to identity a representor to be plugged:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/23.0.0/nova/network/neutron.py#L3360-L3419 (_update_port_binding_for_instance)

Nova has no visibility into representor names used at the SmartNIC DPU host side so it would need to learn those somehow in order to use OVS directly.

How can we manage this without giving the hypervisor host extra visibility into the SmartNIC OS? It's almost like giving a hypervisor host access to programming a ToR.

As far as I can tell, a fundamental point of moving the control plane from the hypervisor host is introducing isolation to the design. So Nova should not even know that there is OVS or something else running on the SmartNIC (much like it does not know what's on the ToR) - it merely needs to grab a VF and wait for a completion from Neutron.

For now, the proposal was about OVN only so Neutron wouldn't handle plugging at all - only pass some information downstream to OVN.

I will rephrase this to avoid too many implementation-specific details and later raise a follow-up.

In testing we hit an issue in the virt driver code since "network-vif-plugged" arrives early before `_create_guest_with_network` sets up a wait for `network-vif-plugged` events via `virtapi.wait_for_instance_event`. So the event is discarded and then the virt driver code blocks waiting for an already discarded event:
                         
1. Neutron notifies Nova when the port status becomes "UP" after Nova does a port update:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/a922e853150003014d03da519d17e6f21d2a333e/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py#L1062-L1063

2. Nova catches up and sets up a wait for the "network-vif-plugged" event:
 * https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e28afc564700a1a35e3bf0269687d5734251b88a/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L7221-L7240
 * https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e28afc564700a1a35e3bf0269687d5734251b88a/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L7191-L7198

deployment/aodh/aodh-base.yaml.message:
It looks like the default values for some of these options in various puppet modules allow users with the 'service' role or the 'admin' role to act as service users.

Keystone's RBAC enforcement has changed over the last year or two and now makes it easier for end users to have administrative rights on projects and domains. This could impact this work if the user has 'admin' on a project and attempts to validate an expired token, even though they're not technically a system administrator.

It might be worth it to only consider "service" roles as valid indicators of service users.

Currently no puppet modules set service_token_roles by default, so the default value in keystonemiddleware, ['service'], is used even if this line is not added.

However I added it to explain explicitly that we use 'service' role for service token feature.

environments/enable-secure-rbac.yaml.message:
Ok - just to make sure, this is going to open any network with the external attribute set to True to any use in the deployment (assuming implied roles are not broken by the operator).

If that's the intent, that makes sense. This also means anyone with a system-scoped token can also view these networks.

I think we're still working out some of those details in the community goal, but for today this probably makes sense.

Yes, that's the intent here. Basically router:external networks are networks which are visible for all users in the cloud. That's how neutron works currently. And that change is just to expose "router:external" attribute for all users - if it's external network it can be shown to users without problem.

web/src/containers/build/Build.jsx.message:
I didn't take a deeper look into this change, but this class here catched my eye 😄

I really would like to keep this a functional component and not introduce new class-based components to the Zuul UI. AFAIK they will become deprecated in react sooner or later. In the last two years the react developers added a lot new functionality to functional components and there isn't much left which requires a class based component.

The most up-to-date components in that regard are the src/containers/logfile/LogFile and /src/containers/FilterToolbar.

It would be awesome if you could have a look at those components and try to update this component accordingly. What you basically can do is to use the useState() hook to implement the state handling rather than define a state dictionary and use setState(<key>, <value>) to update the values. There is a good introduction to those in the React documentation https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-intro.html.

I'd prefer to use a toast here instead of an alert which is what most modern websites do (AFAIK). Green for the success message, red for failure. This would also improve the workflow a little as you don't have to confirm each alert (which makes the website feel unresponsive).
Same idea about the styling of the autohold button like for the re-enqueue in the parent change https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/736772/17/web/src/containers/build/Buildset.jsx#49

style={{ color: 'var(--pf-global--danger-color--100)' }}

Maybe it helps to put the button in the top right corner of the change panel in a separate row (something like a "button bar" above the content) to keep them separated from the content. This might also work well when more buttons are coming (like the promote button from one of the follow up changes).

I hope one can understand what I mean. If not I could also provide an example for this.
I've created a togglable "actions" menu on top of the change panel, would that fit the bill?

I like the design of the new buttons (colord icon + text), but I think having such an expandable section for each change on the status page is too noisy. My original idea would only work without showing the text, but seeing this change now, that one might be also too much.

Another idea: What about using a menu icon (the three dots https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/ellipsis-v?style=solid) and open a small dropdown showing available actions? This way we could keep the style of the actions, but just list them vertically rather than horizontally.

This menu icon could be placed in the top right corner of the current change panel (next to the "remaining time") so we wouldn't need an additional row in each panel.

What do you think about that?

From a usability point of view, we would need two clicks to reach an action, but this is the same for the expandable view (at least in the common case when the view is not expanded yet).
I turned it into a kebab in the next patchset, let me know what you think. However I put it outside of the change panel because I wasn't sure I could get a visually pleasing effect.
Could we include the "Dequeue" into the button and make both clickable?

web/src/containers/build/Buildset.jsx.message:
I think we should make this button less prominent.

I have two proposals in mind (depending on how prominent we want to make this action):

1. We could add a third column to the buildset page (like the link column on the build page) just with a slightly different styling so that one could differentiate between a link and an action. This might work a little better in case we also add links to the build page as on the buildset page this action button might get a little lost.

2. Keep it where it is, but change the styling to look less like a button and more like an action icon. (I'm just writing down what comes to my mind here, but hopefully it's somewhat understandable). E.g. something like the REBASE/ABANDON/EDIT section when viewing a change in Gerrit (top right corner). This could also work if we put the actions between the title and the content  with the different actions next to each other in a single row.

3. Like 2, but with a tooltip instead of the text next to the icon. Depending on the kind of "actions" we are planning to add in the future we could also add some colors to the icons (as long as it doesn't look like a rainbow in the end 😄)

Maybe there is also a combination of 2 and 3 that allows us to show both, icon and text without providing too much visual noise.

The 3. solution might also work as an additional action column in the buildsets table and it would fit the "button/action bar" for the dequeue/promote actions in the change panel.

I'd prefer the 3. solution. For what I have in my mind this feels nice and clean and allows to add additional actions without breaking the style.
I could also just add an "admin" PageSection on top of the summary if the user is an admin. What do you think?
I removed the button, and moved the action icon to the right side of the buildset summary. This can become an "action column" in the future.

Hmm, seeing this now in action I think I'd prefer one of the other solutions. As long as we have only a single "action link" in the right column on the buildset result page this link looks lost. Are we planning to add more actions in the new future?

Another idea: It could also work if we move this action to the second column (below the buildset message) for now. The same could be done for the equivalent action on the build that could be placed below the links in the third column). If we add more actions later on, we could still create a new column.
Hopefully the final update: We should place the icon in front of the action (like for the other links/actions we have so far).

Would it make sense to provide a custom modal/popup instead that looks similar to the confirmation modal? Using an alert here breaks the flow a little.

Maybe it would be even better to provide the success message in form of a toast (I think that is what most modern websites do by now). Green if success, read if failure.
I like the toast. Does it also close by itself? So far I always had to close the toast manually. I think it would be sufficient if it's shown for ~5 seconds and then closes automatically.

It should close automatically, it used the TimedToastNotification[*] component from patternfly-react, see App.jsx

[*] This is not documented in patternfly v4 but is in v3; the default delay is 8 seconds but can be modified with the timedelay property.
I turned this into a notification toast.
I think we should use a redo icon here instead (https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/icons/redo?style=solid)
I don't think we should have 4 columns; that starts to look very crowded on a non-ultrawide monitor.  Why don't we put it below the message above?

I'm on board with actions being distinct from properties, but I think location isn't the only way to do that.  The most important thing is that they are easy to find and identify as actions, and that they don't get lost in the properties.  The styling we have around the button helps a lot with that.  We may be able to improve it some more, and perhaps we think about putting the actions underneath the props.  Anyway, I think this is quite good for now; the benefits outweigh the drawbacks.  Thanks.  :)

UX-wise actions should be distinct from properties; I was also afraid the action would be hard to notice under the message.
I'm not satisfied either with this layout anyway, so let's squeeze this back to 3 columns and if a UX wizard wants to revisit this later, by all means!

web/src/containers/auth/Auth.jsx.message:
nit: I'd prefer if we could keep some kind of import order (like you usually do in python as well) and keep the classes/constants/names per import sorted alphabetically. In my changes I did something like (the comments are just here for explanation:

# base imports
import React from 'react'
import PropTypes from 'prop-types'
import { connect } from 'react-redux'

# patternfly imports (first core, then everything else like icons, table, ...)
...

# other third party imports (like moment.js)
...

# local imports (everything that is referenced by a (relative) path)

Maybe it would be also worth to write a small style guide for this. I know that the zuul project doesn't want to be too restrictive, but I find that this is extremely helpful - especially in JavaScript, where you usually need some time to get used to the code 😄 .
Done

Just as a general note: I'd prefer to use functional components over class based components as they come with much less boilerplate code and IMHO most of their parts are easier to read and understand (especially the usage of states and props). I don't think we should update all the components in this patch as this is now open for quite some time, but if somebody wants to create new components in the future I'd be glad if those are functional components 😊

The rest of the web ui uses classes.  We should maintain consistency.  It's much harder for part-time JS programmers to deal with both at the same time.  If we want to change, we should discuss changing everything.
Please do not change this patch or stack to switch.

FWIW, I personally find the opposite is true.

Definitely a discussion worth having, as new React programmers will most definitely have learned to code using functional components. We don't want to make it difficult for newcomers to contribute. But I think we all agree that this is something to be decided later.

Like I said, I don't think we should change this stack in that regard. I'm also only an "occasional JS developer". When I started with React, they already changed a lot to previous versions (like including the functional components) and there were quite some parts which were marked as deprecated (like the super() call in the class components constructor and AFAIK some of the lifecycle methods changed their name or were also marked as deprecated, e.g. componentWillMount).

And from all I've seen so far, there is clearly a trend in React to move to functional components.

The drawback with all this frontend development is clearly that it changes so fast that you can't really follow-up if you are not working full time on that. But I also think that you should not always stick to one approach because you always did it like that and that from time to time you should try to follow-up on the newer approaches and try to incorporate them. Especially for new features this is something you could do without much of a problem. I did the same when I started with the new UI and I think it was definitely not drawback to do so.
I tried but I hit an error with setting states in two different components. It wasn't very clear ... I'd rather rework this later if needed and keep it that way for now since it works as is.
AFAIK the super() call is deprecated
I think an error is thrown if you try to use "this" in the constructor without calling super(props) first. This is going to be irrelevant once this is turned into a function anyway.
nit: I would place the icon in front of the text, so it's similar to most of the icons we use. But maybe that's only me and the typical "sign out" button has the icon placed behind the text 😄

It's a valid UX discussion. I've checked a few interfaces (github, gerrit, gmail, ...) and it turns out "sign out" buttons usually don't have icons (and are hidden so that people tend to forget logging out, making it easier for these apps to track you, but it's a whole other subject). So I am fine with actually removing it.

Although this renders nicely in (I'd assume all) modern browsers, it gives some nasty exceptions in the console log because a
or
cannot be part of a

. One solution to this would be to use

tags instead of

and take care of the padding/margin via styling/CSS. Another solution could be something like the "About modal" example (which is using a grid) https://www.patternfly.org/v4/components/about-modal

I wanted to suggest that we use a "copy to clipboard" functionality here, but I just discovered that this is already there 😊 However, this wasn't obvious to me in the first place as a click on the button also expands the accordion. That raised the question for me if we even need to show the token or simply change the "Show Token" entry to something like "Copy zuul-client command" that only copies the command on click (we might want to change the onClick handler to work on the whole paragraph and not just the icon). I think this depends on what the main purpose of this field should be. Do we want to show the user the token or is the copy-to-clipboard functionality more beneficially. Although I like the design with the accordion, I find that showing the token doesn't provide too much benefit, if I could simply copy it via a single click instead. If we can't decide on that, we might also provide two actions here. One to copy the token and one to copy the zuul-client command. This would also avoid the issue with the console errors I've mentioned above since there would be no
and
elements nested into

.

Then it might be a good idea to start with only the "copy zuul-client command to clipboard" (without showing the token). This would avoid the warnings in the console and we can simply add more functionality (like downloading/copying) a whole client.conf file.

Regarding the life time of the tokens: Is that something we want to address later on? This feels a little like the "copy login command" functionality from OpenShift (which I use quite often), but there the token is valid for ~1 day. Providing such a functionality for short-lived tokens (~10 mins if I'm not mistaken), would result in a lot of copy-and-paste which feels a little inconvenient.

Showing the token was mostly for debugging purposes, so that I could ensure similar behaviors between the GUI and the CLI.

This should instead be reworked into a way to download a pre-written client.conf file for the tenant. Since many tokens should be expected to be short-lived, the user should be able to choose whether or not to include the current token into the config file.

Ok, that's fine with me. Just one thing: Could we add a `cursor: pointer` style to the PasteIcon? Otherwise it's not clear that you can click it. Or we wrap it into a button that doesn't provide any additional styling.
I just found out there's a clipboard copy component from react, I'll use this in the next PS.

> Then it might be a good idea to start with only the "copy zuul-client command to clipboard" (without showing the token). This would avoid the warnings in the console and we can simply add more functionality (like downloading/copying) a whole client.conf file.
> 

The client configuration is between pre tags now. It doesn't seem to raise warnings in the console anymore.

> Regarding the life time of the tokens: Is that something we want to address later on? This feels a little like the "copy login command" functionality from OpenShift (which I use quite often), but there the token is valid for ~1 day. Providing such a functionality for short-lived tokens (~10 mins if I'm not mistaken), would result in a lot of copy-and-paste which feels a little inconvenient.

The lifetime of tokens is set at the identity provider level. If you're using the test compose, keycloak sets tokens to be valid 15 minutes by default only. It is up to the admin of the identity provider to decide how long-lived the tokens will be, and to provide a way to hand out more permanent tokens if necessary.
(this can be also handled by a zuul operator with `zuul create-auth-token` if a local authenticator is configured)

Based on my limited understand, I suspect we don't need anything because the server never actually receives this data, so it's not collected.

But if the server starts logging usernames, that might make it more relevant.  But then we'd look at the exclusions for required operation.

Having said that, actually just clearly saying what happens with the data isn't a bad thing, and happens to be in the spirit of the law anyway, so maybe we should keep it and just adjust it to be a little more clear?  You've done that in a later PS, so lgtm.  :)
This looks like it's gdpr related.  Have we gotten any advice that this is correct or necessary?  Or is this just being overly cautious?

Overly cautious. This should actually be reformulated to indicate that the user data is never stored server-side and only lives in the browser for the duration of the authenticated session.

If anybody knows the exact legalese, if required at all, let me know!

So what happens is that without adding these, the dev deployment seems to be stuck in a loop. Nothing appears in the console. If someone has an idea how to figure out what is going on exactly, I'll gladly take the suggestion.

That seems suspicious. Is it conflicting with the other state added to the store?

Perhaps this need a comment to explain the motivation of ignoring the redux state invariant.

Perhaps that could be solved by using another store, it seems like we could create it with another react-redux Provider in the App, e.g. after the oidc configuration is known.

Alternatively we could also check if there is a conflict with the state variable name.

Though this may not be a big deal, and we could address that particular issue in a follow-up, to avoid delaying the current stack.

I've looked into using several stores, but everything I've seen advised against doing that. Granted, we seem to allow something bad already, so "in for a penny ..."

I am going to take this opportunity to look into other libraries. Now that I am more at ease with react and redux, it might be easier to use other libs than I previously thought. That'd be ideal too since redux-oidc seems to be dead (lots of issues on GH without answers in the last year).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I don't know what to think of this approach. I think it might lead to corner cases and confusion. I would rather just have any attempts to upload and orig.tar that would overwrite an existing copy be rejected as a failure and force the developer to bump the revision number.

I do want to have developer specific 'scratch' repos, in which case we could restrict this forced overwrite, only if the repo is a scratch one.

Changing anything, even a tiny modification, should be treated as a new release or revision. This is why Debian and Ubuntu treat orig.tar in this way. If I have a software project called ZZZ and do a release 1.2.3 and I then modify a file I have to by definition do a new release, 1.2.4. If I don't do a new release then all sorts of expectations are unmet. I would rather not encourage the behavior of allowing orig.tar to essentially be overwritten. None of the Debian infrastructure allows this and we should be the same. Changes should not be made in orig.tar but in the debian.tar as patches or similar.

If a developer wants to do something with orig.tar we should encourage the use of their local build infrastructure where they can choose to do whatever they want. This is not something we should support and have to remember to avoid when we are doing a release build. Just don't allow this behavior ever.

I suggest this change be dropped. It is not something we want.

Yes, the purpose of this patch is just make "deb-ocal-xxx" "scrach" repos, temporarily, in current develop stage. And, in our design, only one repo is used to store source packages.
As I mentioned in the comment and commit, before we release it, the mechanism should be changed, refuse to upload the whole source package, instead of overwrite the original one. No such scratch repo anymore. Actually, not only the orig tarballs, any files with same name but different content is forbidden in Debian repository.
Copy, then, for such cases, we just output error message and refuse the upload request.

Currently, developers may modify source trees frequently, sometimes only very tiny modification on one single file. I am afraid force them to upgrade version number is too strict for them in current stage.
I am OK for both principles, overwrite the original one or just refuse the upload.
Check your editor's line wrapping length. I am not used to Gerrit but it appears your lines might be a bit long.
Ack
beginning
Done

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This is temporary patch that only used in developing stage.
Currently developer may continuously modify source code and construct *.orig.* files. Debian repository can't deal with such cases, so currently, each time we upload a source package, we check to see if there is already such a file in repository with different size, if so, we suppose the original source package is old and abandoned, we just remove it firstly from the repo, to make sure the new one can be uploaded and deployed successfully.
After this stage, we still need to check such files but once we find such strange files, we will make the uploading failed instead of removing the one in repository.

Compare with the original patch:
-) Check all repositories instead of the target repo; (All repos share the same file pool thus search one single repo is not enough)
-) For duplicate files with different size, if it related to remote repo(mirror), return False; if only local repo related, delete related source packages from all of these repos and then upload the new one.

TODO: before code freeze, modify the principle that once such strange file find, refuse uploading it and return False.

web/src/ZuulAuthProvider.jsx.message: Does it work if oidcConfig is empty? How does this behave if no auth is configured?

We define oidcConfig just above, so it won't be empty, but I assume you mean what if auth_params is empty (which is a component of oidcConfig).

In reducers/auth.js, we default auth_params to the empty string for authority, clientId, and scope.  If there's no previously stored value in localStorage, then we'll use that (also, if we switch tenants, and there's no auth info for the new tenant, the same is true; that's in actions/auth.js).

The AuthProvider accepts these values.  Of course, a login won't work, but we won't display the button in this case anyway.

This is how I picture it:
- install the actual license file into the package from the original source, whatever it is called, eg. COPYING or LICENSE or something else.  Think of it more like a binary that should be installed when a package is installed on the system.
- remove any "extra" license file that the stx designer added when initially introducing the package in the CentOS directories.  Probably one person did it and everyone else just copied the behavior when they introduced other similar driver packages.
- the copyright file is a debian meta-file which should be composed by looking at the actual license in the original source and related copyright.  Copyright is not a synonym for license.  "Licensing gives someone other than the owner a temporary right or permission to use the work protected by copyright while the owner maintains ownership of the copyright" That puppet example you show looks good.

Now all that said, I think it would be better if you didn't do point 1 since the copyright file in point 3 would be installed in /usr/share/doc/<pkg>/ anyway. No sense in installing duplicate info. I checked on a Ubuntu system and all of those copyright files are there, but not, for the most part, the COPYING files from the source itself.  There's just a handful of exceptions.

Seems fine to me.
I assume this means we will never support two different versions of a package at the same time in a repo?

Updated according with Mark's comments.
In addition, added a small update of 'failed' packages list: 
'failed' list = 'all packages scanned to build' - 'success' packages list

At the very beginning, we do support different versions of a package at the same time in a repo. But we get some issues in develop stage, especially on source packages. For some native packages, developers may modify source code and construct source packages frequently. Commonly they should be packages as native source packages instead of quilt ones. But seems developers like quilt format. Once the source tree been modified, a new *orig.tar will be constructed, without rename it. Thus several source packages been constructed, each of them contains a same name *orig.tar but the content of those *orig.tar diff each other. Such case is not supported by Debian repository, ether aptly or pulp.
So, to avoid such issue, we add a check on *tar file before uploading it: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/817721
(BTW, please help to review that very one 😄)
And this one, can also avoid this issue.

On the other hand, deb-local-source is just used to store source packages that will be build by "builders" soon, the newest one should be the one been chosen, so remove the old one is safe, can also save disk space at all. 😊

We will follow the Debian guidelines on this. Debian enforces version uniqueness

https://www.debian.org/doc/debian-policy/ch-binary.html

Section 3.2.2. As such in a single repository we will stick to this rule. Aptly and Pulp allow for the publication of multiple repositories and the LAT can pull from multiple repositories, so there are options available if we have usecases that require this level of 'freedom'.

Yes, the rule of "Uniqueness of version numbers" must be stick to, there is already the lesson. And multiple version packages are still supported with the way Mark mentioned above if there are really such requirements.
Thanks for making all the necessary updates. LGTM

If ofport is the critical data, for ML2 OVS, I have another idea to do the flow installation without adding new ovs-bridges and patch ports.

1. Nova starts live-migration.
2. In the pre-live-migration on destination, nova request neutron to allocate a ofport number.
3. Neutron-server accept this request and send to destanation host's ovs-agent.
4. A valid ofport allocated and saved to port binding profile, then reponse back to Nova.
5. Nova tries to call neutron to bind (multiple bindings) this port to destination host.
6. Neutron ovs-agent uses the binding profiles ofport number to install flows.
7. Nova (libvirt) unpaused the VM and plug the VIF  with the ofport number (flows had been set in 6.)

For 2., Neutron ovs-agent may need to do some refactor of ofport management.
For 6., Neutron ovs-agent needs to add new methods to install flows beyond the OVS-DB monitoring mechanism.
For 7., lib osvif needs to plug ovs-vif with ofport param.

Yep, looks a bit complicated. But for 2. and 6. are popular in large-scale OVS (SDN) controller implementation practice. Flows installation and ofport allocation are handled by controller.

First of all, I would like to remark that the scope of this feature is OVN only. It could be extended to OVS easily (the os-vif implementation is shared between both backends), but is not covered here.

The problem of the interface ofport is not assigning a deterministic ofport number but how OVS provides it. When os-vif creates a port with the corresponding interface, if the TAP port is not present (that is created by libvirt), the interface ofport given is -1 [1].

OVN will use this value interface.ofport, not interface.ofport_request, to write the OF rules in OVS. If the ofport is -1 (invalid), the port won't be provisioned in OVN.

This is what this spec and the os-vif patch specifically want to solve, that is to provide a integration bridge port with a valid ofport BEFORE creating the VM TAP port that is created by libvirt when the VM is unpaused in the destination host. At this moment, OVN should have configured the local OVS to provide communication to this port.

[1]https://paste.opendev.org/show/807459/

This is not a problem of the logic in Neutron, that we are currently using, but how the backend detects a new port, binds it and configures the underlying OF rules to accept traffic from it.

Actually this feature, with minimal changes, could be used in OVS. The goal of this feature is to provide to the backend a port with a valid ofport that will be used to set the proper OF rules, regardless of the TAP device creation, that is done when libvirt unpauses the VM.

The process for Neutron/OVN is the same as we currently have: when the destination port is plugged and detected by ovn-controller, the OVN SB port binding register sets the new chassis (the destination chassis).

But with this feature, as commented, we have a port with a valid interface ofport, that will be used to properly configure the backend (the OF rules, depending on this ofport).

As Sean commented, when the port is plugged during the pre-live migration process. Then Nova commands libvirt to start the migration, using the "live_migration_permit_post_copy" flag [1]. This process should be quick (some times it is not) to unpause the destination VM as fast as possible.

During this guess memory copy, the port is already bound to the destination chassis, with and without this feature. What we need is to minimize the copy time but that will depend on the VM load or the memory configuration. As commented by Sean via IRC, migrating a VM with hugepages implies to re-copy each 1GB page used by the VM during the copy process; VMs with high network throughput will have the same problem.

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/admin/live-migration-usage.html

specs/xena/ovn-plumber-bridge-live-migra.message:
actully no
we plug the ports on the destination in prelive migration before we create the
vm on the destination host.

just before the vm is created in the paused state the tap device is created by libvirt
which is then detacted by ovs and assign an openflow port id since the netdev name matchs the name of the port we created in the ovsdb during pre live migration.


plugging is the act of creating the port in the contolplane of the network backend

e.g. the ovs-vsctl add-port or backend equivalent

it is not the act of creating the interface on the dataplane.

plugging normally happens before interface creation.

Right, Nova (calling os-vif with [1][2]) is capable of plugging the VM port and create the interface, before the TAP device is created. Is the interface ofport what we need to be a valid one.


[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/602432
[2]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/797428
yes. this is partly caused by the fact that ml2/ovn does not send the network-vif-plugged event when it has finished installing the openflow rules as was the original intent of that event.

None of the Neutron backend does it (apart from OVS with hybrid pluggin since [1][2]). Any Neutron backend (OVS, OVN) can't configure anything, if the port interface ofport is invalid.

That was a consensual decision between Nova and Neutron to send the events when (OVS) the port was provisioned or (OVN) when the port binding had "migrating_to" key.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/790702
[2]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/602432
I don't know why I though that was "plumber".

i cannot do this without a change to nova at which point i cannot backport the os-vif changes
as the nova change woudl require a newer min os-vif lib to use this as i would have ot allow nova to pass 2 seperate names.

looking at the nova and neutron code currently we do not support specifyting the name of the port form nutron to nove. we can pass the bridge name but the name of the port on the integration bridge is at novas discression.

by convention we have agreed not to change them but ovn and the ovs l2 agent shoudl soley be using the extrenal_ids info to determin what to do with the port and not then name.

this is not correct in 2 ways.

because ml2/ovn does not seend pulg time event only bind time events today we do not waith in the case of ovn.

because we dont know what ml2 dirver bound the vif we are froce to infer this based on hybrid plug
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/model.py#L464-L481
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/network/model.py#L543-L562

 the second issuse is that we plug the interface in pre-live migration not during the migration.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/compute/manager.py#L8321-L8341
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/compute/manager.py#L8244-L8252

so for backends that send plugtime event we wait to start the migration until we get the network-vif-plugged event.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/compute/manager.py#L8406-L8408
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/compute/manager.py#L8448-L8451

for ovn since it will never notify use when the dest is ready we just start the migration.

ideally ml2/ovn will be modified to notify us when the destination is plugged and then we could wait.

in train https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/train/port-binding-extended-information.html was added but we drop the part about when each driver will send events.

so unfrotently we still do not know if we the backend will send plugtime or bidning time network_vif_plugged events.

we can and should start using that extenion in nova to allow things like adressless prot for l2 networks or differenciate between ml2/ovs and ml2 ovn  to enable vir isolation but we have not done that yet.

I know the interface is plugged during the live-migration. The main problem we have, you know this better than me, is that the interface ofport is invalid. Thus the backend cannot configure the needed OF rules.

We send the vif-plugged-event same as in OVS, "when we can". That was because we didn't have [1] and the port was created and plugged when the VM was unpaused. It is very difficult to tell Nova that the backend is ready when you wait for a "vif-plugged-event" to create the port. The events process was inverted.

This is why [2] was implemented. OVN was unable to send a vif-plugged-event because actually there was not port creation. Then we implemented this workaround to send you the expected event.

Since [1] we can resolve the issue of detecting the port. The issue we want to solve with this spec (and this is your idea that I support) is to both plug a port with an interface with a valid ofport to allow OVN to create the needed OF rules.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/602432
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/97618b08769636ec07b994b26af5d73bae4e5a6c/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py#L796-L815
it should not be required for that case i think since currently we skip waiting in prelive migrate
Then if we skip this waiting time, what is the purpose of this spec? The goal is to have a sequence of sync events and actions. If we skip this time, this spec has no sense.

but yes this would be much better howwever we need somethign in the prot or vif details to know that you send these events or we will have to add a config option in nova to enable waiting with ovn.

i guess a workaround config option to disable waiting with ovn would be better since we woudl want to wait by default and we woudl only disable it for upgrade reasons.


please do implement this in neutron though as i woudl love to remove the hacks we have on the nova side to workaorund this.
unfortuenetly we may still need to keep this for odl altough they were already have ment to fix this.
i jsut dont know if they ever did.
I'll add a flag in the port vif_details, added during the port binding, to identify the backend used.

as i commented on the os-vif patch 
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-vif/+/798055/10#message-25879769ae40bce01578d1c53ce97877c24ccae8

i could also add a new port-ref in the external_ids
    external_ids = {
                'iface-id': iface_id, 'iface-status': 'active',
                'attached-mac': mac, 'vm-uuid': instance_id,
                'port-ref': vif.vif_name
            }

which would hold the name the tap port.

i cannot use the tap**** name on the br-int and teh qos extension and ovn shoudl not make any dependency on the name of the port it should only be using the external_ids as the name of the port is not part of the contact between nova and neutron.

the default devname is hardcorded in nova 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutron.py#L3055-L3056
which is tap<uuid> truncated to 14 letters


when we os-=vif obejcts we just retrive the dev name value form our internel nova vif object
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d03a600461db7d0fe0d6a9f522c30b890c691353/nova/network/os_vif_util.py#L350-L358


when doing hybrid plug for upgrade reason we maintain the old (qvo qvb) names for the veth pair so we do not leak interfaces https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/e93736711920afe64a850f564dddefbd704975cd/vif_plug_ovs/ovs.py#L105-L107 but there is nothing in the api contract between nova and neutorn that would prevent nov or so-vif from changing those since they must not be relied upon by the l2 agent.

it may only depend on the external id and the same is true for ovn.

i have not currently implemeted this for vhost-user but i can add that.

we have never had this reproted for ovs-dpdk but arguably with ovs-dpdk it
not only can happen for migration but also for boot since the ofport-id will be -1 until
qemu adn ovs connect over the unix socket.

Yue, I believe there is still confusion with respect to the orig.tar. Debian maintainers may create the orig.tar but they should neither add or remove contents from the orig.tar. If I am packaging 'dmidecode' I am either cloning a release from https://github.com/mirror/dmidecode and creating a tarball from the contents, or I am downloading an already available dmidecode-X.Y.Z.tar.gz tarball which the upstream project created when they made a release, and renaming it to dmidecode-X.Y.Z.orig.tar.gz.

ALL additions, removals and changes to orig.tar are done via patches.

For reference https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/maint-guide/build.en.html "This is the original upstream source code tarball, merely renamed to the above so that it adheres to the Debian standard."

If debian repack supports local files, we should remove it. This should be done via patches.
Good point of creating patches automatically. I will think about it.

Please follow up with the Bob, Charles and Dan via email or Zoom. Maybe we can continue to support the directory but instead of copying the files have debrepack create the patches and add them to the series automatically? We need to stand firm on orig.tar matching the definition and usage defined in the Debian Maintainers Guide. Thanks.

Yes, we are on same page. 

In fact, for this case, they should use 3.0 native rather than 3.0 quilt, so they can add files arbitrarily, no orig.tag.gz at all. I ever discussed with Bob, Chuck or Dan (I forgot who), they didn't agree with me, and they prefer to use 3.0 quilt for all packages. That is why aptly often crashed(404) due to different orig.tar.gz.

Base on that they need the 3.0 quilt and also want to add local files. Exactly, they need to apply them by patches in theory, but it should be a problem for future maintenance. Mostly, the local files are copied from centos. If we request them to convert the files to patches, they have to maintain 2 set of files, one is in centos/files, ant the other in debian/patches. It requests all developers and reviews to full understand it, and keep them in mind forever, that a fix of centos/files must be update to the debian/patches. 

So the compromise is strictly via patch to add things for a package has the official orig.tar.gz(debian package, or a package with upstream tar ball). For the packages need to create orig.targ.gz locally, we allow them put files in it to avoid maintaining 2 set of files.
