tripleoclient/utils.py.message: I think this should be a variable, you could inspect network_data and look for "service_net_map_replace: storage/storage_mgmt"? If any network has that defined use that networks "name"?

> > OK, what do you think of this?
> > 
> > I'll add a --network-data option which if empty defaults to $THT/network_data.yaml [1]
> > 
> 
> The current default is $THT/network_data_default.yaml:
>   https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/master/tripleoclient/constants.py#L34
> 

So we assume they don't use network isolation. If they require network isolation then they'd pass their network data. Even if the average user might pass this:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml

If someone didn't use network isolation we wouldn't want to set storage and storage_mgmt to what was in the above, it should default to ctlplane. Thus we can't assume they always want the above.

> > I'll also add --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name options whose defaults are storage and storage_mgmt respectively. The program will then search network_data.yaml for whichever network has name_lower set accordingly in order to find what will be the Ceph public and cluster network.
> > 
> > I could also add a --use-service-net-map-replace which defaults to true. When this parameter is true, the program will search not based on name_lower but instead based on service_net_map_replace. For example, if the user passed none of these new options except their custom --network-data, then it would look for "service_net_map_replace: storage" and "service_net_map_replace: storage_mgmt" and then take the associated name_lower automatically. So if the following were in network_data.yaml, then we'd know to use name_lower: storage_cloud_0. 
> > 
> 
> I think the search could look for a matching name_lower first, then a match in service_net_map_replace? I.e matching name_lower has highest "priority". I think the --use-service-net-map-replace option is not required.

So just use a prioritized search instead of having another option to search for one over the other. Good idea.

> >  - name: StorageCloud0
> >    mtu: 1350
> >    vip: true
> >    name_lower: storage_cloud_0
> >    dns_domain: storagecloud0.mydomain.tld.
> >    service_net_map_replace: storage
> >    subnets:
> >      storage_cloud_0_subnet:
> >        ip_subnet: '172.16.11.0/24'
> >        allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.11.4', 'end': '172.16.11.250'}]
> >        vlan: 11
> > 
> > From there I'll also extract the ip_subnet value for that network for the ceph public_network.
> > 
> > If --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name are passed, then it would be recommended that --use-service-net-map-replace be false.
> > 
> > [1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml

OK, what do you think of this?

I'll add a --network-data option which if empty defaults to $THT/network_data.yaml [1]

I'll also add --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name options whose defaults are storage and storage_mgmt respectively. The program will then search network_data.yaml for whichever network has name_lower set accordingly in order to find what will be the Ceph public and cluster network.

I could also add a --use-service-net-map-replace which defaults to true. When this parameter is true, the program will search not based on name_lower but instead based on service_net_map_replace. For example, if the user passed none of these new options except their custom --network-data, then it would look for "service_net_map_replace: storage" and "service_net_map_replace: storage_mgmt" and then take the associated name_lower automatically. So if the following were in network_data.yaml, then we'd know to use name_lower: storage_cloud_0. 

 - name: StorageCloud0
   mtu: 1350
   vip: true
   name_lower: storage_cloud_0
   dns_domain: storagecloud0.mydomain.tld.
   service_net_map_replace: storage
   subnets:
     storage_cloud_0_subnet:
       ip_subnet: '172.16.11.0/24'
       allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.11.4', 'end': '172.16.11.250'}]
       vlan: 11

From there I'll also extract the ip_subnet value for that network for the ceph public_network.

If --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name are passed, then it would be recommended that --use-service-net-map-replace be false.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml

> OK, what do you think of this?
> 
> I'll add a --network-data option which if empty defaults to $THT/network_data.yaml [1]
> 

The current default is $THT/network_data_default.yaml:
  https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/branch/master/tripleoclient/constants.py#L34


> I'll also add --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name options whose defaults are storage and storage_mgmt respectively. The program will then search network_data.yaml for whichever network has name_lower set accordingly in order to find what will be the Ceph public and cluster network.
> 
> I could also add a --use-service-net-map-replace which defaults to true. When this parameter is true, the program will search not based on name_lower but instead based on service_net_map_replace. For example, if the user passed none of these new options except their custom --network-data, then it would look for "service_net_map_replace: storage" and "service_net_map_replace: storage_mgmt" and then take the associated name_lower automatically. So if the following were in network_data.yaml, then we'd know to use name_lower: storage_cloud_0. 
> 

I think the search could look for a matching name_lower first, then a match in service_net_map_replace? I.e matching name_lower has highest "priority". I think the --use-service-net-map-replace option is not required.


>  - name: StorageCloud0
>    mtu: 1350
>    vip: true
>    name_lower: storage_cloud_0
>    dns_domain: storagecloud0.mydomain.tld.
>    service_net_map_replace: storage
>    subnets:
>      storage_cloud_0_subnet:
>        ip_subnet: '172.16.11.0/24'
>        allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.11.4', 'end': '172.16.11.250'}]
>        vlan: 11
> 
> From there I'll also extract the ip_subnet value for that network for the ceph public_network.
> 
> If --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name are passed, then it would be recommended that --use-service-net-map-replace be false.
> 
> [1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml

The value in "subnet" is the subnet name, it does not neccecarily match the networks "name_lower".
For example in a edge deployment it may be:

  StorageMgmt:
    subnet: storage_mgmt_subnet01

While the network name is_
  - name: StorageMgmt
    name_lower: storage_mgmt

The .replace('_subnet', '') whould result in "storage_mgmt01" which is not the correct name.

I think you need to load both roles_data and networks_data, then find the "StorageMgmt" network in network_data.yaml, and get it's name_lower value, with a default to name.lower()

Also, in the edge/splie-leaf case you need to ensure you allocate addresses in a subnet local to the node so you need to get the 'subnet' value as well?

Yeah, .replace('_subnet') is a bad idea. I won't use that. 

In the DCN case or the case where ceph is on a routed network, assuming I know the network they want to use via --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name, I think I would need to identify the correct network and then combine the ip_subnet value for each subnet. 

So If I had this in network_data.yaml

 - name: StorageMgmtCloud0
   mtu: 1350
   vip: true
   name_lower: storage_mgmt_cloud_0
   dns_domain: storagemgmtcloud0.mydomain.tld.
   service_net_map_replace: storage_mgmt
   subnets:
     storage_mgmt_cloud_0_subnet12:
       ip_subnet: '172.16.12.0/24'
       allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.12.4', 'end': '172.16.12.250'}]
       vlan: 12
     storage_mgmt_cloud_0_subnet13:
       ip_subnet: '172.16.13.0/24'
       allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.13.4', 'end': '172.16.13.250'}]
       vlan: 13

Then I would generate a ceph configuration with something like this:

 cluster_network: 172.16.12.0/24,172.16.13.0/24

Does that sound OK?
yes sounds OK. I think both "cluster_network" and "public_network" is a list containing all the ip_subnets of the network in THT.
should this be a separate (nested?) function like get_subnet()?
+1 on the get_subnet function to improve readability

The "net" array (which is the result of yaml.safeload()) can  either have a ip_subnet as a root element .... or a dict like the following: 

{'<subnet name>': {'enabled': '<true|false>',
                   'vlan': '<vlan-id>',
                   'ip_subnet': '<IP/CIDR>',
                   'allocation_pools': '<IP range list>',
                   'gateway_ip': '<gateway IP>',
                   'routes': '<Routes list>',
                   'ipv6_subnet': '<IPv6/CIDR>',
                   'ipv6_allocation_pools': '<IPv6 range list>',
                   'gateway_ipv6': '<IPv6 gateway>',
                   'routes_ipv6': '<Routes list>',
                   'external_resource_subnet_id': '<Existing subnet UUID (optional)>'}}
                   'external_resource_segment_id': '<Existing segment UUID (optional)>'}}

where multiple networks are specified.
This means you try to make a net.get(ip_subnet) and return it (the best case), otherwise you need to get the "subnets" dictionary (if present) and parse it, looking for the 'ip_subnet' key (it depends if it's ipv6 or not, and this depends on a input passed to the command).
Yes, exactly. Thanks for writing a summary of what is happening. My next PS will have a comment in this function to document it based on what you wrote above.

I see you don't need subnet_name (as it's not used).
Lets' say you have something like:

 subnets:
    tenant_leaf1:
      vlan: 41
      ip_subnet: '172.16.1.0/24'
      allocation_pools: [{'start': '172.16.1.10', 'end': '172.16.1.250'}]
      gateway_ip: '172.16.1.254'
      ipv6_subnet: 'fd00:fd00:fd00:4001::/64'
      ipv6_allocation_pools: [{'start': 'fd00:fd00:fd00:4001::10', 'end': 'fd00:fd00:fd00:4001:ffff:ffff:ffff:fffe'}]
      gateway_ipv6: 'fd00:fd00:fd00:4001::1'

Once you get the 'subnets' dict, you want to parse each subnet and return a comma separated list made by the retrieved values.
Since you don't need to match the subnet_name, this loop can be turned into:

for subnet_dict in net['subnets'].values():
    if ip_subnet in subnet_dict:
        ip_subnets.append(subnet_dict[ip_subnet])
return ','.join(ip_subnets)

or ... (but it should be tested), those three lines can be turned into: 

ip_subnets = list(map(lambda x: x.get(ip_subnet), net['subnets'].values()))
return ','.join(ip_subnets)
Nice translation. Now how can I resist not using map and lambda for this?
maybe can be: if net.get(search_tag, None) ==  net_value
Thanks, that's more a concise way to express the same operation. I'll switch to that.
Use net.get('ipv6', False) in the loop below to determine which key to use.
Done

'name_lower' is not mandatory in net_data, we default name_lower to name.lower() if it is not defined.
I think we should iterate over net_data first and set 'name_lower' if not already set.
i.e something like this before the loop on L3259:

  [net.setdefault('name_lower', net['name'].lower()) for net in net_data]
Done

tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_ceph.py.message:
Is there a way to set these manually?

In a scenario where completely custom names are used and/or the "ServiceNetMap" entries are set to map Ceph services to a different network there must be a way to map the networks ceph deploy uses.

I.e the user decide not to use Storage and StorageMgmt for Ceph and uses CephNetwork and CephMgmtNetwork instead. But the "Storage" network exist for other things, Swift in this example.

ServiceNetMap:
  SwiftStorageNetwork: storage_mgmt
  SwiftProxyNetwork: storage

  CephClusterNetwork: ceph_mgmt_network
  CephGrafanaNetwork: ceph_network
  CephMonNetwork: storage_mgmt
  CephRgwNetwork: ceph_network

I think the ability to set these manually will be addressed by the --public-network-name and --cluster-network-name options I described in my other comment.

E.g. If they pass --public-network-name=ceph_network and --cluster-network-name=ceph_mgmt_network it would use those keys to get the appropriate network values from network_data.yaml

Do we need this?
We don't support using both IPv4 and IPv6 elsewhere.

When creating networks/subnets as IPv6 the 'ipv6' key for the network must be set to true, see:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L437

i.e you can determine which version to use from the network-data provided. If ipv6 != true you pick the IPv4 keys, else pick the ipv6 keys. See: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L270-L305

> Do we need this?
> We don't support using both IPv4 and IPv6 elsewhere.

We didn't support it for ceph services via ceph-ansible, though cephadm allows for dual stack:

https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rados/configuration/network-config-ref/#ipv4-ipv6-dual-stack-mode

But if TripleO won't support it in general then I will remove the option:

 --ip-version {4,6,both}

I read "For configuring both IPv4 and IPv6 on the same interface..." in the following so I thought we'd support both. 

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml#L82-L84

I assume you're saying we support v4 and v6 on one interface but don't let any services use both.

> When creating networks/subnets as IPv6 the 'ipv6' key for the network must be set to true, see:
> https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L437
> 
> i.e you can determine which version to use from the network-data provided. If ipv6 != true you pick the IPv4 keys, else pick the ipv6 keys. See: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L270-L305

I don't see an example of this in the following:

 https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml

Can you confirm the syntax would be like this?

 https://paste.opendev.org/show/811174/

> > Do we need this?
> > We don't support using both IPv4 and IPv6 elsewhere.
> 
> We didn't support it for ceph services via ceph-ansible, though cephadm allows for dual stack:
> 
> https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rados/configuration/network-config-ref/#ipv4-ipv6-dual-stack-mode
> 
> But if TripleO won't support it in general then I will remove the option:
> 
>  --ip-version {4,6,both}
> 
> I read "For configuring both IPv4 and IPv6 on the same interface..." in the following so I thought we'd support both. 
> 
> https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml#L82-L84
> 

Yes, so using two different networks you can do it, i.e if you have storage_ipv4 and storage_ipv6 networks, and then in nic-config you assign two addresses to the same interface.

> I assume you're saying we support v4 and v6 on one interface but don't let any services use both.
> 

Indeed, the ServiceNetMap in THT would control which network the service is configured to use. And that would be either the ipv4 or the ipv6 network.

> > When creating networks/subnets as IPv6 the 'ipv6' key for the network must be set to true, see:
> > https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L437
> > 
> > i.e you can determine which version to use from the network-data provided. If ipv6 != true you pick the IPv4 keys, else pick the ipv6 keys. See: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_composable_network.py#L270-L305
> 
> I don't see an example of this in the following:
> 
>  https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/network_data.yaml
> 
> Can you confirm the syntax would be like this?
> 
>  https://paste.opendev.org/show/811174/

Yes, ^^ syntax is correct.

There are examples here:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/tree/master/network-data-samples

It might be nice to make this non-exclusive so they can also pick "4,6" and then we do dual-stack support [1]. In that case we'd want to concatenate both ipv6_subnet and ip_subnet (switch from an either or to another loop). Then we would also pass the ms_bind_ipv4 and ms_bind_ipv6 options as part of ceph.conf assimilation. In the past we didn't support this with ceph-ansible [2][3] so it would be nice to add.

[1] https://docs.ceph.com/en/latest/rados/configuration/network-config-ref/#ipv4-ipv6-dual-stack-mode

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml#L598-L602

[3] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/83a8dd5a6a1f9ffe43b2a75d7b49775e34c58f24/roles/ceph-config/templates/ceph.conf.j2#L10-L13

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I would suggest changing this phrase to something like: "In order to correctly update the monitor, a monmap backup is generated during the backup process and then it is restored and injected into the monitor's database during the restore process."
Done
Why do we need this? Why doesn't the existing procedure work?

So, we verified for B&R on 21.12 -> 21.12 ceph mon logs are showing an initial monmap configured by default.

---------------- initial monmap ---------------------------------
2021-11-12 16:09:31.547 7f13177ca1c0  1 initial generated monmap:
epoch 0
fsid 50ce952f-bd16-4864-9487-6c7e959be95e
last_changed 2021-11-12 16:09:31.548351
created 2021-11-12 16:09:31.548351
min_mon_release 0 (unknown)
0: [v2:192.168.204.1:3300/0,v1:192.168.204.1:6789/0] mon.noname-a
------------------------------------------------------------------

When the monitor reads ceph.conf file, it is searching for itself but it can't find because the host name from monmap is "mon.noname-a" and this is not updated.

----------------------- monitor can't find itself in ceph.conf -----------------
2021-11-12 16:09:35.874 7fa520fee1c0  0 mon.controller does not exist in monmap, will attempt to join an existing cluster
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

After this, it tries to join to an existing cluster, but no cluster exists on AIO-DX/AIO-SX and it stays in a loop.


----------------------- monitor stays in loop ---------------------------
2021-11-12 16:09:35.880 7fa520fee1c0  0 -- 
[v2:192.168.204.1:3300/0,v1:192.168.204.1:6789/0] send_to message mon_probe(probe 50ce952f-bd16-4864-9487-6c7e959be95e name controller new mon_release 14) v7 with empty dest 
2021-11-12 16:09:36.454 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
2021-11-12 16:09:36.657 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
2021-11-12 16:09:37.059 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
2021-11-12 16:09:37.862 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
2021-11-12 16:09:37.881 7fa50c25d700  0 -- [v2:192.168.204.1:3300/0,v1:192.168.204.1:6789/0] send_to message mon_probe(probe 50ce952f-bd16-4864-9487-6c7e959be95e name controller new mon_release 14) v7 with empty dest 
2021-11-12 16:09:39.455 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
2021-11-12 16:09:39.656 7fa50da60700  1 mon.controller@-1(probing) e0 handle_auth_request failed to assign global_id
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

The logic used was to to make a backup of monmap and after it is restored, it is injected into the monitor, so it can recover itself.

I investigated this. The issue here stems from the fact that we are no longer providing the port for the public_addr of the monitor. This was removed with https://opendev.org/starlingx/config/commit/09e0401d59d94cf619f3810244c5ff882f6a9213 and is not present the restored ceph.conf.

If we define a port, either v1 (6789) or v2 (3300), for the monitor's public_addr, then the restore playbook will work without us needing to change the backup.

Since we still have older containerized ceph clients using the V1 protocol (another problem -> need up upgrade apps to use V2), then we can't use the V2 port because we'll have no easy way to enable the V1 protocol.

I'd prefer as solution that does the following by just updating the recover-ceph-data role:
 - add the V1 address to the monitor's public_addr before starting the monitor and executing recover_ceph_data.py
 - after restoring the monitor DB and bringing up the monitor/OSDs, execute 'ceph mon enable-msgr2' then wait for the msgr2 cluster warning to clear.
 - On host unlock the V1 port will be removed due to the commit mentioned earlier

How big is the monmap file? I believe it will be consistently, relatively small. Any factors that would cause it to produce a large file? As this will be included in the backup, will this have an impact on the how much space we need to have for backups (i.e. the backup partition)

I'm not opposed to adding the missing files in ldapscripts-templates.patch.

I just wonder which is cleaner: 
1) Adding files through a patch.
2) Using a dl_hook to pull the files from MY_REPO(https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/containers/+/812290) + sources from salsa. + maybe do a copy of the files since they might diverge?


Also I think we should disable the unit tests... 30 minutes and still counting. I don't see them enabled in rpm spec either.

One reason of not using dl_hook to copy the local files is dl_hook should handle whole downloading process. For the Debian native package, we just use the formal steps (apt source) to download/extract. 

Another reason is the major reason is copying a file to source directory (${PKG_BUILD_NAME}) and the package format is 3.0 quilt, at the end, running dpkg-buildpackage to repack the .dsc/.debian.tar.gz, it fails with error

====================
building a source package without cleaning up as you asked; it might contain undesired files
====================

As 3.0 quilt, the source codes must be same with .orig.tar.gz, and any change should be via patches, so I use a patch to add local files. Another choice is copy local files to debian folder not source directory.
Ingore the unit tests comment, that is for another review.

Why are we hard-coding rather than using helm overrides?

toolkit:
The nvidia-toolkit pod when started with "defaultRuntime: containerd" will overwrite /etc/containerd/config.toml and restart the service. To avoid this, we disable the toolkit installation and instead "pre-install" the toolkit using a sub-chart. The version is hard coded in the sub-chart.

defaultRuntime:
When set to containerd, eliminates the need to (1) create "nvidia" runtimeClass, and (2) reduces the number of patches to assets/*/*yaml because the operator will inject the correct "runtimeClass: nvidia" into each pod spec under assets/*/*yaml.

Will remove the hard coded value and allow for override on (1) driver, and (2) defaultRuntime. The toolkit will be pre-installed (version 1.7.1-ubi8).

nova/compute/manager.py.message: This does not seem necessary. get_available_nodes already returns a list.

unfortunately, I think this part is still needed for security reasons... the reasoning is fake driver requires init_host called before get_available_nodes... and it will return None otherwise which causes _get_nodes failed...

I'd tend to think we should update the fake driver to better reflect reality instead of accounting for it here in the real implementation. Prior to your change, init_host was always called before get_available_nodes but your change demonstrates that it's valid to call get_available_nodes first ... So maybe we should just init the fake driver's _nodes = [] instead of doing this?
Done
This does not seem necessary. And _get_nodes returns a dict, not a list.
Done
Note to self: this is a dict keyed by consumer uuid (which maps to instance uuid).

At first I thought this is redundant because allocations were already retrieved on L1424 but this is different in that it is pulling allocations for an instance from all resource providers. AFAIK the only time we expect an instance to have allocations on more than one resource provider is during a migration.

ok, you catch the same exception for three calls, it's fine.

TBC, I would have preferred to have a catch for every call, but given the provided exceptions are the same, that's OK

That's actually why I'd prefer to have a specific catch for every call, because here we don't know whether we got an exception because of a missing customer, a missing node or a RP and also, *which one*

Honestly, this debug log can't help operators. Also, should it be a debug level or a warning one ?
thank you for reviewing it. if making it warning, this implies that there will be a warning log  every time a new nova-compute node starts.. I am afraid this might be confusing...

i think you should catch the atribute error if the driver has not beeen updated to accpet kwargs

catching the error and calling driver.init_host(self.host) will allow out of tree driver to work and we can drop that after yoga has released.

also -1 for useing the kwargs syntax for host which is a postional arg
Done

I think this is broken. This calls self.driver.get_available_nodes() but we haven't called self.driver.init_host() yet so the driver is probably not ready yet. So this call will always return an empty dict.
seems reasonable, but the self.driver.get_available_nodes() really can get the current host's name.

I think we should not use the libvirt connection before driver.init_host. See [1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ee91d92f9105aa7e7b1e45a47f70b8989b458a68/nova/virt/libvirt/host.py#L609-L612

As self.driver.get_available_nodes() uses self._host therefore using the libvirt connection to get the nodes I don't think it is safe to use before driver.init_host. The comment in [1] clearly state that we should not use the libvirt connection before the error handlers are set up. As those are set up in init_host we should first call init_host and then we can start using get_available_nodes()
Not exactly, we can get node_name by getHostname(), and get node by node_name.
nit, as gibi says below.

This logic also finds the migration consumers against this compute RP which we need as an ongoing migration still consumes VGPUs on the source host so recreating the mdevs for it is needed e.g. if the migration is later reverted and therefore the VM needs to be restarted on this host.
This assumes that all nova managed allocation has resources from the root RP (node_uuid). This assumption holds today, but I suggest to document this assumption in a comment here.

nit: instead of backslash I suggest to use ():

                  consumer_dict[consumer] = (
                      self.reportclient.get_allocations_for_consumer(
                            context, consumer)
                  )
nit: ditto
we can filter vgpu rp here and transport only vgpu rps.

This can return None at least in two distinct cases. 
1) The RP does not exists in placement, i.e. first start of the compute service
2) The connection towards placement is failing (see the save_connect decorator on top of the _get_resource_provider call). It can be network issue, config issue etc.

This later in the libvirt driver will lead to TypeError

What if placement is down when the compute is restarting while there are instances on the host with VGPU. I think with this patch we call init_host without allocation information and the libvirt driver will log "instance %s allocates vgpu device but does not have allocations in placement". This is misleading as in this case we simply don't know if there are allocation in placement or not as placement was down.

I don't know what will be a good solution. @Others: should we block compute startup if placement is not available?
gibi, if placement service is down, we cannot start nova-compute service and reach here.
hm, where do we have that code that blocks starting nova-compute if placement is down?

when the nova-compute service is start, it will create service at[1], nova-compute will init ComputeManager, and generate reportclient at[2], the SchedulerReportClient will call Placement to create placementclient[3]. so if placement service is down, nova-compute will break at starting.
https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/cmd/compute.py#59
https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/compute/manager.py#535
https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#188

Ups, you are right. The nova-compute service fails to start if placement is down. (With a misleading error:  Unhandled error: openstack.exceptions.NotSupported: The placement service for 192.168.121.179:RegionOne exists but does not have any supported versions.)

I've just realized that ResourceProviderAllocationRetrievalFailed is not raised if the RP does not exists, in that case the call returns None. Also this is not raised if placement cannot be reached as that will be caught by the safe_connect decorator on top of _get_resource_provider() and that also returns None.

I don't think we should ignore ResourceProviderAllocationRetrievalFailed and move forward. We should stop the compute service startup instead. Right now Placement does not declare any other response code other than 404 and 200 (both handled without ResourceProviderAllocationRetrievalFailed). So whatever resulting in a ResourceProviderAllocationRetrievalFailed should be a serious problem warranting us to just top.
This is not true, if placement returns 404 then the report client does not raise ResourceProviderAllocationRetrievalFailed exception but simply returns None.
nit: I would mention in the log that it is OK if this is the first start of the compute
I'm not sure we should take up complexity for the out of tree virt drivers. I think an ML post notifying them about the interface change should be enough instead.

Hi @sbauza! I believe this change will not fix the problem, because since we do not have the vgpu instances persisted in the OS, we will have an exception in line 980 (mdevs = self._get_all_assigned_mediated_devices()) - VIR_ERR_NO_NODE_DEVICE. Could we just catch the exception and create the previous existent mediated devices setting parent to None, like:

                try:
                    dev_info = self._get_mediated_device_information(dev_name)
                    parent = dev_info['parent']
                    parent_type = self._get_vgpu_type_per_pgpu(parent)
                    if dev_info['type'] != parent_type:
                        # NOTE(sbauza): The mdev was created by using a different
                        # vGPU type. We can't recreate the mdev until the operator
                        # modifies the configuration.
                        parent = "{}:{}:{}.{}".format(*parent[4:].split('_'))
                        msg = ("The instance UUID %(inst)s uses a VGPU that "
                               "its parent pGPU %(parent)s no longer "
                               "supports as the instance vGPU type %(type)s "
                               "is not accepted for the pGPU. Please correct "
                               "the configuration accordingly." %
                               {'inst': instance_uuid,
                                'parent': parent,
                                'type': dev_info['type']})
                        raise exception.InvalidLibvirtGPUConfig(reason=msg)
                except libvirt.libvirtError as e:
                    errcode = e.get_error_code()
                    if errcode == libvirt.VIR_ERR_NO_NODE_DEVICE:
                        parent = None
                    else:
                        raise e
                self._create_new_mediated_device(parent, uuid=mdev_uuid)

could fail as rp can be None if:

2) the safe_connect decorator on top of _get_resource_provider catches connection error / configuration error etc when connecting to placement and therefore _get_resource_provider returns None which the manager stores in provider_dict passed here as rps

This is slightly misleading. If you need the root provider then you can use the root_provider_uuid field of the RP directly. Today's nova RP tree is created in a way that the VGPU RPs are the direct children of the root RP so parent_provider_uuid and root_provider_uuid is the same for the VGPU RP. /COMMIT_MSG.message:
i will point out that we do not follow the legacy release with milestones release model
https://github.com/openstack/releases/blob/61f891ddd7bd3b28ac7b5e7e9e1d9203fbbe297d/doc/source/reference/release_models.rst#cycle-with-milestones

we use cycle-with-intermediary

https://github.com/openstack/releases/blob/61f891ddd7bd3b28ac7b5e7e9e1d9203fbbe297d/doc/source/reference/release_models.rst#cycle-with-intermediary

which allows use to do release at any time during the cycle and just requires use to make at least 1 release a cycle. we do not need to make one every milestone and i think its actully incorrect to release every milesone unless there has been a resonable change in the code base.

there is nothing too presseing that i want to hold the release for although i would like to get the mypy serirese merged this cycle
https://review.opendev.org/q/project:openstack/os-vif+branch:master+status:open

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
+1 for now although in general i done think we shoudl be releaseing every milestone like this unless we have more content in the release. the optimisations in 

https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/commit/09c0629bb728ad342a41d844143d8e7437c925c4
and
https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/commit/e4dc8b5664ccee8bde9e90fc9e618d6b705a0b68

are important however so we shoudl release and backport them.

i would like to hold any release on stable branches until those are backported

Thanks Sean for the explanation, I haven't been aware of the evolution of the release models :)
On the other hand now we have a task in the release process to "Propose autoreleases for cycle-with-intermediary libraries which did not release since the previous release" for Milestone-1. This is only necessary for projects that has any merged changes that worth releasing, though. So yes, i think it's not necessary at this point, but why not release then? o:)

And for now: thanks for the +1s, the generated release looks fine to me.
Approved by release liaison (thanks!). Generated patch looks good to me.

charm-recheck

I'm not convinced that the solidfire enablement belongs in the cinder-netapp charm. I realize that the device is now a NetApp Solidfire device, but they carry no other similarities other than branding and I feel that this would be best in its own subordinate charm.

For future reviewers - I've also done some upgrade testing on this change to ensure the charm has the right behaviours.

On charm upgrade (at focal and later) the .config gets removed and the .conf written, and RMQ restarted (this will need a release note).

On series upgrade (bionic->focal) the .config file is removed and the .conf file written prior to the RMQ service being started as part of the series upgrade complete step.

Thank you for your work on this, however if we want to remove this specific deprecation warning, the target of the change would be charm-helpers itself.

Unfortunately juju has gone through a actions -> functions and back to -> actions round, but the fact remains that actions are actions, and the helpers that refer to the "function" name should be removed.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'm confused, is the problem that the pool is exhausted (too many connections in use)?  Or that there are too many connections open to the db (connection pool not being shut down)?  Or that there are too many open sockets( connection pool not being shut down)?

The pool is per-process and we would never run more than one scheduler in a process (only in the unit tests will that happen).

The scheduler now performs db reads and writes synchronously, in the main loop, so it should only ever have one connection at a time active.  If we imagine a unit test with 2 schedulers and one zuul-web, that still only adds up to 3.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
There is a documentation error unrelated to this patch:

/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/.tox/docs/lib/python3.8/site-packages/keystoneauth1/fixture/discovery.py:docstring of keystoneauth1.fixture.discovery.DiscoveryList:1:duplicate object description of keystoneauth1.fixture.discovery.DiscoveryList, other instance in api/keystoneclient.fixture, use :noindex: for one of them

Couple suggestions to line this up with the API reference. Also a link to some similar tests that we can use.

https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/831ba037b0ba2077e168cb33976c78e565aece88

Thanks for the patch, Radomir!

Looks good outside of a couple minor comments about wording.

This worked locally for me and the tests make sense.

keystoneclient/v3/auth.py.message:
We need to drop the 's' otherwise we get a 404.

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/index.html#get-available-system-scopes

Tested this using a areally quick functional test with devstack:

  from keystoneauth1.identity import v3
  from keystoneauth1 import session
  from keystoneclient.v3 import client

  auth = v3.Password(auth_url='http://192.168.1.154/identity/v3',
                     username='admin',
                     password='nomoresecret',
                     user_domain_id='default')
  sess = session.Session(auth=auth)
  ks = client.Client(session=sess)
  systems = ks.auth.systems()
  for system in systems:
      assert system.all

This needs to be _SYSTEMS_URL to match the constant above:

  *** AttributeError: 'AuthManager' object has no attribute '_SYSTEM_URL'
The 's' here could be dropped to be consistent with everything else. I'm indifferent, curious what other people think.
This will only ever be one today. It could be expanded in the future, but that would require additional keystone work that isn't planned, yet.

keystoneclient/v3/system.py.message:
Another way to think of this is that it represents the entire deployment system, including all services in the cloud you're interacting with.

It might be more accurate to say something along those lines.

keystoneclient/v3/systems.py.message: nit: The year of the copyright header looks incorrect.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hey guys, can you please take a look at this change?
Marked as WIP again to test some things, please don't review yet
Thanks for waiting, the code may be reviewed now
Needed to do rebase so the sysinv fix for zuul/tox gets included as part of the parent commit chain
This change needs to be updated with the current OpenStack version

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/pci_i.message: This returns a boolean, should be something like: is_supported_by_pci_irq_agent_container
this note should be above the method signature.
I could be wrong, but this should be the other way, no?

No, the agent platform service should be disabled if OpenStack contains the containerized agent (so False if has container support), but anyway I changed the variable name including 'service' on it to try to be clearer
Are we enabling the pci irq affinity agent platform service even when the openstack application is not active? Is it really necessary?
The logic is wrong indeed, but this part of the code won't ever be executed because of the check on line 42. Thanks for pointing that out.

I think this should be wrapped in a try block.
We could encounter an exception if that app does not exist.
https://github.com/starlingx/config/blob/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L7840

Since there is a check with utils.is_openstack_applied(self.dbapi) before calling this function it is highly unlikely that an exception would be raised, but I put it on the try block because in case that the version is not parsed correctly, so that's the reason of the broader exception clause.
I think the build will be 124, after the merge of https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/openstack-armada-app/+/813247. Let's see on tomorrow's build.
Built the stx-openstack and the version came as 125. I will wait for tomorrow's build to confirm and then update here. Thanks for raising this discussion.

tempest/lib/base.py.message:
+1 for this but instead of new class, we can add this in test.py BaseTestCase [1] itself and then you do not need to add multiple inheritance. test.py is stable interface for all the plugins.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/test.py#L75

the use case of this is not clear to me. Now test can request project member or project alt members from tempest[1], do we still need this?

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/keystone_scopes_and_roles_support.html#project-scoped-personas

This is probably obsolete now that you've added the necessary plumbing for $PROJECT scope and $ALT_PROJECT scope. I think we should be able to cover nearly all our bases with those.

We can add this back in if we absolutely need it, or we can add another official persona if there is enough need for it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Same here - use EnableSecureRbac?

deployment/barbican/barbican-api-contain.message: do you think we could add a global setting, which can be as well controlled on a per service basis, just like we do for the Debug flag?
There is pep8 failure here, this 'if' block needs to be moved to left.

I think EnforceSecureRbac need to be defined in this template as well, since this template is not inheriting any settings from keystone service and even after enabling 'EnforceSecureRbac' from [1], babrbican api service will not consume parameter enabled via parameter_defaults.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781571/14/environments/enable-secure-rbac.yaml#42
That should be EnableSecureRbac as defined in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/806449/1/deployment/keystone/keystone-container-puppet.yaml#370 , or not?
Nevermind, this was named EnableSecureRbac in patchset #1.

Should this be specific to Heat? Can we assume the keystone-container-puppet variable exist here or no?

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/806449/3/deployment/keystone/keystone-container-puppet.yaml
